column4: hello. one question: I runned this cmd (sudo apt-get install sun-java6-bin sun-java6-jre sun-java6-jdk). It says me java is his latest version and when i type java -version it says me no such file or direcotry
type java and hit TAB once or twice
i did and i got some .directories and files
what does    ls /usr/bin | grep java  say?
huh. so the compiler is there, but the runner is not?
you need to use --install, I think, not -install
most of the time, whole-word command line options are prefixed with a -- (two hyphens) and single letter options with - (one hyphen)
you installed the package openjdk-6-jre?
on my system, java is linked to /etc/alternatives/java, which is further linked to /usr/lib/jvm/java-6-openjdk/jre/bin/java
the main graphical package manager for Ubuntu
those aren't folders. those are options from the gnome menu.
from the sun website you mean?
Don't they have instructions there for that?
that installer does not use Ubuntu's package management system.
the .bin from Sun's website its an executable binary. You have to give it executable permissions.
yes, then go the directory that contains it and then type ./whateveritis.bin
uploading synaptic to the machine? what?
oh, so you don't have graphical access?
in that case, synaptic is no use to you.
the closest thing to synaptic if you only have command line access is aptitude
otherwise, run aptitude and type / to start searching for packages by name.
